data.title: PRTM EDGE Final EXAM Questions AND Answers 2023 Complete
data.meta_description: PRTM EDGE Final EXAM Questions AND Answers 2023 Complete-12 prtm edge final exam questions and answers 2023 complete go above beyond to exceed guest would best
data.text:
"I go above & beyond to exceed Guest expectations." would best describe which one of Disney's 4 keys. a. show b. courtesy c. safety d. efficiency: b

Municipal organizations are most likely to be found in which sector? a. Public b. Private Non-Profit c. Commercial d. None of these choices are correct: a

Organization Q was formed by a special charter and is owned by share- holders who have limited liability. Organization Q is most likely from the sector. a. Commercial/Private for Profit b. Public c. Private Non Profit d. None of the choices are correct: a

According to the article, "Welcome to the Experience Economy", what key experience-design principle "must drive all the design elements and staged events of the experience toward a unified story line that wholly captivates the customer?" a. Mix in memorabilia b. Eliminate negative cues c. Theme d. Engaging all five senses: c

The National Park Service is an example of what sector? a. Public b. Commercial/Private for Profit c. Private non-profit d. None of the choices are correct: a

The YMCA is an example of what sector? a. Commercial/Private for Profit b. Private non-profit c. Public d. None of the choices are correct: b

According to the Social Equity of the NRPA Pillars, universal access to public parks and recreation is a right

There are 4 NRPA Pillars are Conservation, Sustainability, Social Equity, and Health & Wellness. a. true b. false: b

What is the 1st of the 4 Disney Keys? a. Courtesy b. Show c. Efficiency d. Safety: d

501(c)3 is the tax code that legally signifies a nonprofit organization. a. true b. false: a

According to the reading A Framework for Thinking Ethically, ethics should be based on religious beliefs. a. true b. false: b

Ethical dilemmas can only be dealt with using one's gut or intuition; systematic reasoning can never be applied to such dilemmas. a. true b. false: b

According to article from the Rutland Institute for Ethics, one can be confident in his/her ethical decision making if there is convergence from multiple ethical frameworks. a. True b. False: a

Which of the following frameworks for the reading A Framework for Thinking Ethically views ethical action as one that best protects and respects the dignity of human life? a. The Common Good Approach b. The Fairness or Justice Approach c. The Rights Approach d. None of the choices are correct: c

Which of the following shows the correct order of steps in the Rutland Center's four-step approach to ethical decision-making?

Based on your readings, what is interpretation?: An art combined with other arts Aim is provocation Aim to present a whole not a part Info diluted to to children Not information

Provide 2 tangibles and 2 intangibles of the tiger paw?: Intangibles- Clem- son family, Orange=happy color Tangibles- a Tigers paw, Clemson University

Explain and provide one example of personal interpretation: tour guide

Explain and provide one example of non-personal interpretation.: map

Explain what a universal concept is and provide 3 examples.: Universal Concept- proven across subject areas -Clemson founded in 1889 -Tiger paw turned at 1 o'clock -Clemson is in the playoff semi final game

Who developed the theory of the hierarchy of needs, where the goal is to help people reach peak experiences and self-actualization?: Maslow

What was the name of the Antarctic explorer you read about?: Ernest Shackleton

Please name two things he was known for (you can't say he was known for going to the Antarctic).: -People wanted to follow him -Not a single member of his 28 person team died in 2 years of being stranded

In the National Park Service reading, much attention is paid to the skills interpreters need. Please complete the triangle by listing the necessary component of an interpretive opportunity.: left- knowledge of resource right- knowledge of audience bottom - appropriate techniques middle - interpretive opportunity

Changing elements of an activity or format so that it can be adapted to participant ability or need is called activity clustering. a. true b. false: b

Goals are broad statements of purpose, and objectives are measurable statements of specific intentions.

The mission statement allows the leisure service organization to articu- late which of the following? a. To what extent they have been successful b. What they are trying to accomplish c. Who they are providing services for d. All of the choices are correct: d

What are the two fundamental types of program objectives? a. Human service and service delivery b. Fiscal and performance c. Implementation and outcome d. None of the choices are correct: c

When an activity or format is broken down into parts so that its structure and characteristics can be analyzed, that is called a. Format check b. Activity analysis c. Program assessment d. Program retrenchment: b

This type of program format often has different organizational patterns such as tournaments, contests, meets and leagues. a. Competition b. Open facility c. Instructional d. Special interest groups: a

For a logic model of the EDGE semester, "classroom space "would be considered what type of component? a. Input b. Impact c. Output d. Outcome: a

For a logic model of the EDGE semester, "Improved leisure programs throughout the state of South Carolina "would be considered what type of component? a. Input b. Activity

Which of the following are the four steps of process describe in the reading on risk management as a starting point for dealing with risk? a. Identification, Evaluation, Treatment, Implementation b. Assessment, Implementation, Evaluation, Planning c. Identification, Evaluation, Planning, Insurance d. Identification, Evaluation, Diagnosis, Implementation: a

The US legal system is based primarily on: a. Common Law b. Contract Law c. Law & Order d. Municipal Codes: a

Which of the following exemplifies a high threshold training method? a. Access to professional resources b. Job shadowing and coaching c. Networking and meetings d. Professional certification or license: d

Which of the following best describes human relations skills? a. Ability to analyze situations from multiple perspectives, determine cause and effect, etc. b. Ability to work with, lead, and understand people. c. Job specific knowledge and techniques d. Resources and systems an organization has in place to meet its human resources needs: b

Which of the following interview questions is considered an acceptable question to ask someone you are interviewing for a job? a. Are you married? b. Do you have any health conditions that might hinder your ability to attend work on a regular schedule? c. Have you ever worked for this company under a different name? d. Where were you born?: c

This term is defined as "a process that involves establishing a "person- ality" for a company or product/service in the minds of some target group."

According to the 4Ps of marketing, what "P" addresses the following question: Where and when can you get across your marketing messages to your target market? a. Price b. Product c. Place d. Promotion: d

This term describes "everything a company does to deliver a product/ser- vice to its target markets." a. Public Relations b. Marketing c. Branding d. Advertising: b

The "promotional mix" consists of these 2 elements: a. Advertising & Branding b. Advertising & Public Relations c. Branding & Marketing d. Marketing & Public Relations: b

Unconventional ways to bring attention to an idea or product or service like using flash mobs, viral campaigns, graffiti, or other unexpected methods. Legally, an employer can ask a job candidate the following question: "Where were you born?" a. Direct marketing b. Guerilla marketing c. Product placement d. Sales promotion: b

In order to establish an effective brand, it is not important to be consistent (using same colors, images, tagline, messaging, etc.). a. True b. False: a

The statement that outlines how your business products, or services differ from your competition is called brand strategy.

Which budgeting system appropriates a specific dollar amount to each expenditure identified in the budget? a. Line-item budget b. Performance budgeting c. PPBS d. Zero-based budgeting: a

When deciding how much to charge for an activity or service, a program- mer must engage in what type of process? a. Cost allocation b. Pricing differentials c. Economic impact analysis d. Direct cost assignments: a

Which of the following is an example of a fixed cost? a. Staff salaries b. Support service (trash, police, medical) for a program or service c. Promotional materials d. All of the choices are correct: d

If a person with disability wanted to participate in a program and needed a sign language interpreter and it did not cause undue burden, you would ... a. Add that cost of the interpreter to the price of the program for that person b. Provide an interpreter at no additional cost to the person c. Ask them to bring their own interpreter d. Tell the person that they cannot participate: b

When a program is subsidized, you would a. Give out scholarships to all needy participants b. Make all programs free to everyone c. Take the revenue earned from one program and use it to reduce the cost of another program d. Make more revenue than if you did not subsidize programs: c

If you were operating a program at "full cost recovery", you would... a. Differentiate prices based on product b. Be the most inclusive of all constituents c. Cover overhead costs, but charge enough to make up operating costs d. Charge enough to cover the total costs of running the program: d
